citation.article-title: Clostridium vincentii sp. nov., a new obligately anaerobic, saccharolytic, psychrophilic bacterium isolated from low-salinity pond sediment of the McMurdo Ice Shelf, Antarctica.

p.s: Description of Clostridium vincentii sp. nov.
Clostridium vincentii (vin.cen'ti. i.L.gen.n. M.L. masc.gen.n., of Vincent, in honour of Warwick Vincent for his contribution to our understanding of microbial ecosystems in Antarctica)
Slightly curved rods, 0.6 x 5 μm, motile with peritrichous flagella.
Temperature range for growth, 2–20° C; optimum, 12° C.
Survives freeze-thawing at low salt concentrations, but not exposure to temperatures (25°C for more than 20 h or short-term exposure to temperatures of 50° C or higher).
Energy for growth derived by fermenting xylan and hexose mono- and disaccharides (including N-acetyl glucosamine) to acetate, butyrate, formate, hydrogen and CO2.
No lactate, ethanol, n-propanol, n-butanol, propionate or succinate are produced as fermentation end products.
Cellulose, starch, glycogen, rhamnose, sorbitol, valine, isoleucine, fumarate, lactate, formate, glycerol, malate, yeast extract and casamino acids are not utilized as substrates for growth.
Nitrate and sulfate are not utilized as electron acceptors.
The organism was isolated from sediment below the cyanobacterial mat of a low-salinity pond on the McMurdo Ice Shelf in Antarctica.
